==Events==
*[[539 BC]] &ndash; [[Cyrus the great]] (founder of [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian Empire]]) entered capital of [[Babylon]] and allowed the Jews to return to their land.
* [[312]] &ndash; [[Constantine the Great]] enters Rome after his victory at the [[Ponte Milvio|Milvian Bridge]], stages a grand ''[[Adventus (ceremony)|adventus]]'' in the city, and is met with popular jubilation. [[Maxentius]]' body is fished out of the [[Tiber River|Tiber]] and beheaded.
* [[437]] &ndash; [[Valentinian III]], [[Western Roman Emperor]], marries [[Licinia Eudoxia]], daughter of his cousin [[Theodosius II]], [[Eastern Roman Emperor]] in [[Constantinople]] unifying the two branches of the [[House of Theodosius]].
* [[969]] &ndash; [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] troops occupy [[Antioch]] [[Syria]].
*[[1268]] &ndash; [[Conradin]], the last legitimate male heir of the [[Hohenstaufen]] dynasty of [[List of German Kings and Emperors|Kings of Germany]] and [[Holy Roman Emperor]]s, is executed along with his companion [[Frederick I, Margrave of Baden]] by [[Charles I of Sicily]], a political rival and ally to the hostile [[Roman Catholic Church]].
*[[1390]] &ndash; First trial for [[witchcraft]] in Paris leading to the death of three people.
*[[1422]] &ndash; [[Charles VII of France]] becomes king in succession to his father [[Charles VI of France]] though he isn't officially crowned king until 1429.
*[[1467]] &ndash; [[Battle of Brustem]]: [[Charles the Bold]] defeats [[Liège]].
*[[1611]] &ndash; Russian homage to the King of Poland, [[Sigismund III Vasa]].
*[[1618]] &ndash; English adventurer, writer, and [[courtier]] Sir [[Walter Raleigh]] is beheaded for allegedly conspiring against [[James I of England]].
*[[1658]] &ndash; [[Battle of the Sound]].
*[[1665]] &ndash; [[Battle of Ambuila]], in which Portuguese forces defeat the forces of the [[Kingdom of Kongo]] and [[decapitated]] king [[António I of Kongo]], also called Nvita a Nkanga.
*[[1675]] &ndash; [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibniz]] makes the first use of the [[long s]] (∫) as a symbol of the [[integral]] in [[calculus]].
*[[1787]] &ndash; [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s opera ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' receives its first performance in [[Prague]].
*[[1792]] &ndash; [[Mount Hood]] ([[Oregon]]) is named after the British naval officer Alexander Arthur Hood by Lt. William E. Broughton who spotted the mountain near the mouth of the [[Willamette River]].
*[[1863]] &ndash; Eighteen countries meet in [[Geneva]] and agree to form the [[International Red Cross]].
*  1863   &ndash; [[American Civil War]]: [[Battle of Wauhatchie]] &ndash; Forces under [[United States|Union]] General [[Ulysses S. Grant]] repel a [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] attack led by General [[James Longstreet]]. Union forces thus open a [[supply line]] into [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]].
*[[1886]] &ndash; The first [[ticker-tape parade]] takes place in New York City when office workers spontaneously throw [[ticker tape]] into the streets as the [[Statue of Liberty]] is dedicated.
*[[1888]] &ndash; The [[Convention of Constantinople]] is signed, guaranteeing free maritime passage through the [[Suez Canal]] during war and peace.
*[[1901]] &ndash; In [[Amherst, Massachusetts]] nurse [[Jane Toppan]] is arrested for murdering the Davis family of [[Boston]] with an overdose of [[morphine]].
*  1901   &ndash; [[Capital punishment]]: [[Leon Czolgosz]], the assassin of U.S. President [[William McKinley]], is executed by electrocution.
*[[1918]] &ndash; The [[German Empire|German]] [[High Seas Fleet]] is incapacitated when sailors [[Wilhelmshaven mutiny|mutiny]] on the night of the 29th-30th, an action which would trigger the [[German Revolution of 1918–19]].
*[[1921]] &ndash; The [[Link River Dam]], a part of the [[Klamath Reclamation Project]], is completed.
*  1921   &ndash; Second trial of [[Sacco and Vanzetti]] in the United States of America.
*  1921   &ndash; The [[Harvard University]] football team loses to [[Centre College]], ending a 25 game winning streak. This is considered one of the biggest upsets in college football.
*[[1922]] &ndash; King [[Victor Emmanuel III of Italy]], appoints [[Benito Mussolini]] as Prime Minister.
*[[1923]] &ndash; [[Turkey]] becomes a republic following the dissolution of the [[Ottoman Empire]].
*[[1929]] &ndash; The [[New York Stock Exchange]] crashes in what will be called the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929|Crash of '29]] or "Black Tuesday", ending the Great Bull Market of the 1920s and beginning the [[Great Depression]].
*[[1941]] &ndash; [[The Holocaust]]: In the [[Kaunas Ghetto]] over 10,000 Jews are shot by [[Nazi Germany|German]] occupiers at the [[Ninth Fort]], a massacre known as the "Great Action".
*[[1942]] &ndash; The Holocaust: In the United Kingdom, leading clergymen and political figures hold a public meeting to register outrage over [[Nazi Germany]]'s persecution of Jews.
*[[1944]] &ndash; The city of [[Breda (Netherlands)|Breda]] in the Netherlands is liberated by [[1st Polish Armoured Division]].
*[[1945]] &ndash; [[Getúlio Vargas]], president of [[Brazil]], resigns.
*[[1948]] &ndash; [[Safsaf massacre]].
*[[1953]] &ndash; [[BCPA Flight 304]] [[DC-6]] crashes near [[San Francisco]]. Pianist [[William Kapell]] is among the 19 killed.
*[[1955]] &ndash; The {{ship|Soviet battleship|Novorossiysk}} strikes a World War II mine in the harbor at [[Sevastopol]].
*[[1956]] &ndash; [[Suez Crisis]] begins: [[Israel]]i forces invade the [[Sinai Peninsula]] and push [[Egypt]]ian forces back toward the [[Suez Canal]].
*  1956   &ndash; The Tangier Protocol is signed: The international city [[Tangier]] is reintegrated into [[Morocco]].
*[[1957]] &ndash; [[Israel]]'s prime minister [[David Ben-Gurion]] and five of his ministers are injured when a [[hand grenade]] is tossed into Israel's parliament, the [[Knesset]].
*[[1960]] &ndash; In [[Louisville, Kentucky]], Cassius Clay (who later takes the name [[Muhammad Ali]]) wins his first professional fight.
*  1960   &ndash; An airplane carrying the [[Cal Poly football team plane crash|Cal Poly football team crashes on takeoff]] in Toledo, Ohio.
*[[1961]] &ndash; [[Syria]] exits from the [[United Arab Republic]].
*[[1964]] &ndash; The United Republic of [[Tanganyika]] and [[Zanzibar]] is renamed the [[Tanzania|United Republic of Tanzania]].
*  1964   &ndash; A collection of irreplaceable [[gemstone|gem]]s, including the 565 carat (113 g) [[Star of India (gem)|Star of India]], is stolen by a group of thieves (among them is [[Jack Roland Murphy|"Murph the surf"]]) from the [[American Museum of Natural History]] in New York City.
*[[1967]] &ndash; London criminal [[Jack McVitie]] is murdered by the [[Kray twins]], leading to their eventual imprisonment and downfall.
*  1967   &ndash; [[Montreal]]'s World Fair, [[Expo 67]], closes with over 50 million visitors.
*[[1969]] &ndash; The first-ever [[computer]]-to-computer link is established on [[ARPANET]], the precursor to the [[Internet]].
*[[1971]] &ndash; In Macon, Georgia, guitarist [[Duane Allman]] is killed in a motorcycle accident.
*[[1972]] &ndash; The three surviving perpetrators of the [[Munich massacre]] are released from prison in exchange for the hostages of hijacked [[Lufthansa Flight 615]].
*[[1980]] &ndash; Demonstration flight of a secretly modified [[C-130 Hercules|C-130]] for an [[Iran hostage crisis]] rescue attempt ends in crash landing at [[Eglin Air Force Base]]'s Duke Field, [[Florida]] leading to cancellation of [[Operation Credible Sport]].
*[[1985]] &ndash; Major General [[Samuel K. Doe]] is announced the winner of the first multi-party election in [[Liberia]].
*[[1986]] &ndash; British Prime Minister [[Margaret Thatcher]] opens the last stretch of the [[M25 motorway]].
*[[1991]] &ndash; The American [[Galileo spacecraft]] makes its closest approach to [[951 Gaspra]], becoming the first probe to visit an [[asteroid]].
*[[1994]] &ndash; [[Francisco Martin Duran]] fires over two dozen shots at the [[White House]] (Duran is later convicted of trying to kill US President [[Bill Clinton]]).
*[[1997]] &ndash; [[Anton Lavey]], founder of the [[Church of Satan]], dies in [[San Francisco]] of [[pulmonary edema]]
*[[1998]] &ndash; [[Apartheid]]: In South Africa, the [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (South Africa)|Truth and Reconciliation Commission]] presents its report, which condemns both sides for committing atrocities.
*  1998   &ndash; [[Space Shuttle Discovery]] blasts off on [[STS-95]] with 77-year old [[John Glenn]] on board, making him the oldest person to go into space.
*  1998   &ndash; [[ATSC]] [[HDTV]] broadcasting in the United States is inaugurated with the launch of [[STS-95]] space shuttle mission.
*  1998   &ndash; While ''en route'' from [[Adana]] to [[Ankara]], a [[Turkish Airlines]] flight with a crew of 6 and 33 passengers is hijacked by a [[Kurd]]ish militant who orders the pilot to fly to Switzerland. The plane instead lands in Ankara after the pilot tricked the hijacker into thinking that he is landing in the [[Bulgaria]]n capital of [[Sofia]] to refuel.
*  1998   &ndash; [[Hurricane Mitch]], the second deadliest Atlantic hurricane in history, makes [[Landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] in [[Honduras]].
*  1998   &ndash; The [[Gothenburg nightclub fire]] in Sweden kills 63 and injures 200.
*[[1999]] &ndash; A [[1999 Odisha cyclone|large cyclone]] devastates [[Odisha]], India.
*[[2002]] &ndash; [[Ho Chi Minh City ITC fire]], a fire destroys a luxurious department store where 1500 people are shopping. Over 60 people die and over 100 are unaccounted for. It is the deadliest disaster in Vietnam during peacetime.
*[[2004]] &ndash; The Arabic-language news network [[Al Jazeera]] broadcasts an excerpt from a [[2004 Osama bin Laden video]] in which the terrorist leader first admits direct responsibility for the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] and references the [[2004 U.S. presidential election]].
*[[2005]] &ndash; [[29 October 2005 Delhi bombings|Bombings in Delhi]] kill more than 60.
*[[2008]] &ndash; [[Delta Air Lines]] merges with [[Northwest Airlines]], creating the world's largest airline and reducing the number of US legacy carriers to five.
*[[2012]] &ndash; [[Hurricane Sandy]] hits the east coast of the United States, killing 148 directly and 138 indirectly, while leaving nearly $70 billion in damages and causing major power outages.
*[[2013]] &ndash; [[Turkey]] opens a [[Marmaray|sea tunnel]] connecting [[Europe]] and [[Asia]] across the [[Bosphorus Strait]] in [[Istanbul]].
